utterances: Now, you've got to keep it brief, though, we only have enough time to get all three answers.
OK.
I'm working, I'm working, so I'm not having any fun.
Faye?
This is Baratunde, I'm having a great time.
I've been doing a lot of live video.

People can check it out at jackandjillpolitics.com and finding some of those stories that wouldn't make it to the news from delegates, to alternative media outlets, to local Denver residents who are just excited to have the convention in town.
Faye, you're going to get the last word.
Talk if you will briefly about security.
There's protests, there's parties, how all of that...
I assume you mean Princella.
Did I say Princella?
No, you said Faye.
That's OK.
No, I did mean to say Faye.
Faye, that's who I'm asking the question of.
In terms of...
Well, OK.
That's the difference.
I should give it a plug.
Please go visit AOL Black Voices.
I'm actually here covering the convention for AOL Black Voices.
The difference between the convention - my first one in '84 and today is the difference between night and day.
The security really takes away some of the excitement of a convention, to be able to move around freely, to flit from hotel to hotel.
Now, as a credentialed journalist I don't have a problem.
But for guests and those who want to be part of this historic event, they can't even get into a lot of places simply because of the security.
So next week, what do we have to look forward to?
Really quickly, Princella.
Next week, you've got a great lineup of speakers.
You're going to see the real story of John McCain being told.
That's something that the campaign has struggled with a bit is talking about how great of an American hero he is, and he is going to have to introduce himself to the American people.
I think he will.
I think you will definitely see substantive things as far as a comprehensive plan on energy, a comprehensive plan on immigration, a comprehensive plan on national security.
So, that's what people have to look forward to next week.
So, we will end the conversation there.
I want to thank all of you for being with me.

We have been talking with Baratunde Thurston, he blogs at the Huffington Post and Jack and Jill Politics, and citizen journalist and public policy consultant Faye Anderson, who blogs at Anderson at Large and NPR's election blog Sunday Soapbox.
Both were at our special NPR studio in Denver.
Princella Smith, national spokesperson for American Solutions, a non-partisan organization funded by former Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich.
She blogs at American Solutions and is a guest blogger for our show.
Now you can read her daily dispatches from the political conventions at our blog, nprnewsandviews.org.
And she was at the Audio Ruckus Studio in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The conversation doesn't stop there, though.
Our online series Speak Your Mind gives you the chance to sound off on the issues that you care about.
Go to nprnewsandviews.org and click on Speak Your Mind.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
In the coming weeks, millions of college students will move into dorm rooms, make new friends and hit the books.
And if that sounds pretty much like the experience of their predecessors over the years, some things have changed.
In this economy, the pressure to succeed can be overwhelming.
Students worry about choosing the right major to land a job.

Add the mounting cost of college, living expenses and another factor: College deans report the biggest change over the past decade is parental involvement on campus, and their expectations can add pressure, too.
If you're in college, how is it different than you thought?
Give us a call: 800-989-8255.
Email: talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our website.
Go to npr.org and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Later in the program, we want to hear from athletes, whether you set a world record at the Olympic Games or a personal best on the elliptical down at the gym, how did you surpass your limits?
Email us: talk@npr.org.
But first, Arthur Levine joins us from a studio in Atlanta.
He's president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation and president emeritus of Teacher's College at Columbia University.
And it's nice to have you with us today.
It's nice to be with you.

And that note about college deans and parents is among the findings of a survey conducted for a new book you co-wrote with Diane Dean called ""Generation on a Tightrope."" I think it's safe to say there's always been pressure to succeed.
What's different now?
The economy really is a big deal.
This is a generation that's graduating college with two-thirds owing more than $31,000.
What's also true is they're in a world in which they're working more.
They're taking fewer courses.
They're stopping out for periods of time because they can't afford to stay in.
They're working longer hours, and they're choosing majors in career areas they don't necessarily want.
Being more pragmatic, if you will.
Much more pragmatic than the students who came before them.

And as they make those choices, it's interesting to me, one of the findings was that over 40 percent of students get A-minus or better on their average grade - their grade-point scores, but they also feel underappreciated.
They're worth more than that.
But it was really thought of as more of a parlor trick.
Another $58 billion will be spent during the next six years.
The Bush administration plans to have up to 54 long-range interceptors after 2010, including as many as 10 interceptors in Europe.
Coyle says building such a robust system is easier said than done, and there may never be an effective missile shield.
It's hard for Americans not to want technology to be a kind of silver bullet, the thing that will solve all of our problems.
But sometimes technology just isn't there when we want it.
Depending on what the threat becomes, it becomes harder and harder for missile defense.
Still, Coyle says there are some promising parts of the missile defense program.
The Navy has had success in its EGIS program, basically ships with advanced radar and missiles that can shoot down a warhead.
Others seem some hope in an airborne laser, which could potentially zap a missile out of the sky, perhaps sometime in the next decade.
Tom Bowman, NPR News, the Pentagon.
The new government of Pakistan is negotiating a ceasefire agreement with Pushtun tribes whose lands border Afghanistan.
This is the area where al-Qaida and the Taliban are strong and the talks are causing some consternation in Washington.
The Pakistani government is lead by the party of the late Benazir Bhutto.
One of the key people they are negotiating about is the man who the U.S.
and the previous Pakistani government say was behind her assassination.
For more on the agreement, we turn to NPR's Philip Reeves, who's in Islamabad, Pakistan.
Philip, welcome.
And first, who is negotiating with whom and how far have the negotiations gone?
Well, on one side you've got tribal elders of the Mehsud tribe, that's one of the main tribes in Wizeristan.
And on the other side you've got the representative of the government of Pakistan.
Now, one official reportedly today said that talks are in an advanced state, and that they have the backing of the Pakistani military and senior political leaders in Islamabad.
It should be said, though, that they don't directly involve Baitullah Mehsud.

Now he's the man as you mentioned, the - the Pakistan, Taliban leader accused by the CIA and General Pervez Musharraf, when he was in power, of being behind Benazir Bhutto's assassination - although many in Pakistan dispute whether he was or not.
However, Pakistani government officials have negotiated with Mehsud before.
Some months back, for example, when he took several hundred of their soldiers hostage they talked with him.
And under the terms of the agreement, as it's been developed so far, what would each side do?
What would the government do and what would the Mehsud tribe do?
Well, this agreement's been seen by several news organizations, including the New York Times, and they say that it has 15 points.
Broadly speaking, the Mehsud tribal people would agree that they'd play no part in attacks on government forces or suicide attacks in Pakistan throughout the country.

They've agreed to expel foreign militants from that territory within a month of signing the deal, and to provide information on militant training camps, and to release government officials that they've been holding hostage, and to respect also the writ of the state in the tribal areas.
In return, they get the release of prisoners, they get development projects and the withdrawal of Pakistan's regular army forces from their area.
Now is this the very kind of deal that - the U.S.
and Benazir Bhutto herself faulted Pervez Musharraf for making, that is, conceding some control of the tribal areas to militant tribal leaders?

Well, the government's writ never really ran in Wizeristan, but yes it's true that Bhutto was critical - very critical - of Musharraf for not taking a tough enough stance, in her view, against the Islamist militants.
Islamist extremism was one of her strongest paths, her strongest theme on the campaign trail.
Can we go back to one provision of this 15-point agreement?
That is to say the Mehsud tribal leaders saying that - within, I gather, a rather short period time, they would get rid of foreign fighters in their area.
How significant is that?
Well, it depends on how much weight you give to the claims that al-Qaida is strong in that part of the tribal areas.
That is the claim that's been made by the U.S.

But it is disputed by some of those who study the area, who say that the people who are strong there are principally the Taliban, rather than al-Qaida, although they do not dispute that there are some foreigners in the area, including for example, Chechens and Uzbeks.
Clearly getting rid of them from the area is a priority for the Pakistani government because it's in the draft agreement.
So, it does appear to be that the presence of foreigners is an issue there.

The U.S., and of course the government neighboring Afghanistan, would place a lot of weight on the foreigners in the tribal areas as a problem for them and they do believe that it is a base - a significant base for al-Qaida.
Do these negotiations, involving the Pakistani government, does it suggest a different policy in Islamabad toward the United States and are there implications here for U.S.-Pakistani relations?

Well, top officials from the new coalition government in Pakistan have said from the moment they were elected that they favored negotiating with militants including the Taliban - though they say they wouldn't negotiate with all militants, they did say they would negotiate with militants and the tribal areas.
Now, the new government says that it does recognize the threat of Islamist extremism, but it wants to tackle the issue in its own way and not in Washington's way.
NPR's Phil Reeves in Islamabad.
Thanks a lot, Phil.
You're welcome.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
MELISSA BLOCK, host
